Sentencas: Fuel cells represent a challenging overlap of catalysis and electrochemistry.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: This is illustrated by anode reactions in a solid oxide fuel cell.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: The sites for catalytic conversion of methane and electrochemical conversion of hydrogen on an SOFC anode appear not to be the same.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: The fuel (methane, hydrogen, etc.) is activated by chemisorption on the nickel surface of the anode.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: This is linked to the electrochemical reaction at the interface of the electrolyte and the nickel crystals converting oxygen ions into electrons and water by reactions with adsorbed hydrogen atoms resulting from the activation of the fuel.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: The sites for these reactions appear not to be the same.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: This is reflected by different sensitivities of the two steps to sulphur poisoning.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: The role of different sites on the nickel surface for the steam reforming reaction is well understood in terms of impact on activity for methane activation, carbon formation and sintering.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode

Sentencas: The study is supplemented by an analysis of anodes having been exposed to 13000 of operation using a number of characterisation methods.
Titulo: Sites for catalysis and electrochemistry in solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode
